climbs.name: Totally Tubular
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Denise Brown, January 1983

content.description: This is a totally cool route up a triangular enclosed chimney located to the right of For Sure and to the left of Squeeze Play.  Excellent climbing with a puzzling exit sequence.
content.location: This is inside an interesting configuration of large flakes approximately 50 yards south of Beak Boulder.

climbs.name: Throbbing Gristle
climbs.fa: (TR) Alan Nelson, 1983; First Lead: Sean Villanueva Odriscoll, 2014 (?)

content.description:
This rig is a true classic and an odd one for Josh. There are no real face holds, knobs, or crumbly edges to help you. It is overhanging, somewhat flared and leaning.

The rock is very good at the bottom, to the point of being slick inside the crack. Higher up the rock starts to deteriorate, but alas, I never got there... denied!

This route might be the best OW I have seen or tried in Josh.

more info here:

WideFetish.com
content.protection:
For the lead you will need a few #6 Wild Country cams, and then some stuff to about 3" to finish off to the summit.

For the TR, a couple of slings and biners will do the trick. Two bolt anchor on top.
content.location: This route is approached much the same way as Kamikaze. Approach time is about 40 minutes if coming in from the road, and not the Split Rock parking area. When you get to the Beak Boulder rocks, skirt the crag to climbers right, instead of left towards Kamikaze. This route is about 150 feet left of Kamikaze. Go up towards the top of the formation where the arrows are in the beta pic. Up on the false summit there will be a point where you can crawl through a giant multiheaded Yucca. Down and right goes to the base of the route, and up and left will get you on the summit. There are two bolts on top for the toprope.

climbs.name: Squeeze Play
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Denise Brown, January 1983

content.description: This route climbs to the top of the boulder where the bomb bay chimney begins.  Bold moves up the unprotected flare are necessary until one can place a large cam.  The crux comes up higher where the crack thins out and the flare pushes you out.
content.protection: The largest cam you own would get some use on this one.
content.location: This route is located just to the right (south) of Totally Tubular on the outside of the flake that makes up the right wall of that route.

content.description: After clipping the first bolt off a boulder make the crux moves up and right.  Climb up slab past 3 more bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
From the area with

Totally Tubular

and

Bath Water

etc.  Move towards the formation with

Beak of the Week

etc.  continue right around this formation towards the start of

Super Beak of the Desert

.  Continue towards the actual Beak Boulder.  You'll come to a corridor with a route on the actual face of the Beak Boulder and 3 routes on the formation opposite the Beak. This is the middle four bolt route starting off a high boulder.

content.description:
Face climbing past four bolts leads to an anchor shared with Beak of the Week.

Two bolt anchor that has rappel tat and a Quick link for lowering.
content.protection: Four bolts. Anchor now has quick links and  rings.
content.location: Backside of the knife edge arete just SW of the Beak Boulder.

climbs.name: Sleek Beak
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Rob Stahl, Todd Gordon, May 1987

content.description: Up the center of the steep broad face on the inside corridor side, with Beak of the Week aound to the left and Super Beak of the Desert around and above to the right.  Only 3 protruding buttonheads with rusty hangers "protect" about 2/3 of the way up.  Then either the route veers left and up to join the 4th bolt of Beak of the Week to finish up that (might this be why that bolt was left as a protruding buttonhead with rusty hanger as well on Beak of the Week, in stark contrast to the rest of its modern solid bolts?), or veers right and up via subtle features (some breakable) and much grainy choss to run it out up to the shared anchor. Original PG rating presently more like R/X due to the dilapidated lead bolts.
content.protection: 3 relic bolts, same bolted anchor with slings, quicklink, and biner shared with Beak of the Week and Super Beak of the Desert.
content.location: The steep flat (north) face between the Beak of the Week arete around to the left and Super Beak of the Desert corner edge around to the right.

content.description: This is the left of two routes and diagonals slightly left at the start as it passes through a lighter colored rock scar.
content.location:
Located on a south-facing, pyramid shaped block in front of

Canadian Bacon

.

content.description: A nice wide outing for the neophyte O-dubber.  This route requires some ability to use wide skills, but also allows you to get good hand jams deep in the back.
content.protection: I used a single rack from #1 camalot to #4.5 (old size)camalot with doubles in the old #3-#3.5.  (The #1 and #2 go well in the anchor at the top).
content.location: This route is located on the backside of the beak boulder.  It is difficult to find the routes, but be aware that they are in a corridor that is behind the big bird looking boulder.

content.description: From a large boulder clip the first bolt and work your slabtastic self up through the next 3 bolts.
content.location:
From the area with Totally Tubular and Bath Water etc.  Move towards the formation with Beak of the Week etc.  continue right around this formation towards the start of Super Beak of the Desert.  Continue towards the actual Beak Boulder.  You'll come to a corridor with a route on the actual face of the Beak Boulder and 3 routes on the formation opposite the Beak. This is the left four bolt route starting off a high boulder.

From the "path" heading around the bigger formation, head up boulder past

Unknown #1

and throw yourself to the next boulder left.

content.description:
Crux is right off the ground, and maybe at a pod about half way up.

Good pro anywhere you want it.

Even though the rock in the area seems like total crap, the rock on this route is very good, even to the point of being slick.

additional info:

WideFetish.com
content.protection:
Starts out fat taking a #6 Wild Country for the opening moves. From here it is mostly fist until an easy hands section near the top. Bring a few extra in the 2" to 3" range for the anchor on top.

For the route: 1 2" cam, 2 3" cams, 2 4" cams, 1 5" cam, 1 6" cam
content.location: Getting out to the route will take about 35 - 40 minutes. Park at Split Rock, and head out towards Morongo Man. Eventually you will hit a marked trail going East towards the Bond Boulders and Tiger Rocks. (see approach map). Continue past Tiger Rocks going East and as you drop over the next saddle, you will see the Beak Boulder (see approach map). Kamikaze is on the back side of the Beak Boulder formation, on the North East face. To the left of Kamikaze is another wide crack rated 10a, and further left is Throbbing Gristle, 5.12a

content.description: Chimney inside of the Bath Water arete fin.  Tighter and much easier version of Firewater Chimney, with similar rightward bend as one ascends.  Listed as 5.3 PG in Bartlett's Pinto Basin book.
content.protection: Big and extra big gear, bolted rap anchor atop Bath Water.
content.location: Obvious gap formed by the Bath Water sharp fin.

content.description: The right of the two routes that angles left and joins it's neighbor at the anchors.
content.location:
Located on a south-facing, pyramid shaped block in front of

Canadian Bacon

.

content.description: Buff slab. Stiffer than it looks. A little crispy.
content.protection:
6 bolts, anchors. Bring a long extension for the anchor as it is a ways back.

Walk off to the right or rap from anchors atop

Bath Water

.
content.location:
20 feet to the right of

Bath Water

.

content.description: Step across a gap at the base of the route and pull into the crack.  Climb the sweet, but short hand crack.  After the first 20 feet the angle eases.
content.location: When facing the southwest side of the Beak Boulder area, Desert Queen is the conspicuous hand crack on the tier below, and to the right of the Beak Boulder.

content.description:
A stellar, arete climb with an entrance crux. Gain the knife edge through stemming and an awkward high step, then climb the ridge to the top.

Two bolt anchor on the opposing side with rappel tat and quick-link.

2+ star climbing in a three star area.
content.protection:
6 bolts to the Anchor.

Anchor now has quick links and rings.
content.location: Large knife edge boulder just SW of the Beak Boulder.

content.description: Climbs a thin crack that passes through two horizontal cracks - at the second one cut left to finish.
content.location: Located on a small south-facing block down below the prominent Beak Boulder.

content.description: Awesome climbing up an arete. I started up the chimney to get established. From there transfer to the backside of the arete and then up and around. Continue up the fully featured arete to the top.
content.protection:
6 bolts to lower off.

I'd suggest pulling your rope from far back so it doesn't get snagged.
